user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__poll:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__poll (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.epoll)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-e' or '--epoll'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.select)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-s' or '--select'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.poll = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the fragments above because they are the points where control flow decisions and assignments occur and therefore are the likely locations for unreachable-code issues when viewed in the wider project context. Other parts of the function (signature, braces, simple line breaks) are syntactic and do not contain alternate branches or code placed after an unconditional control transfer that would make them unreachable. To determine if any of the selected fragments are actually unreachable requires project-level context (e.g. possible values and initialization of tool_params flags, and how process_param__poll is called), which is why those specific fragments were flagged for further investigation.
